title: How to Cook Sunflower Sprouts

steps.headline: Whisk together shallot, garlic, vinegar, olive oil, salt, and pepper.
steps.description: Set aside for later. Rinse the vegetables for later as well.

steps.headline: Bring 4 cups (1 L) of water to a boil.
steps.description: Cook over medium to high heat. This will be enough for 9 ounces (255 g) of sunflower sprouts. You can prepare more sunflower sprouts if you want to, but you'll need to add more water. If you are cooking more bean sprouts, use enough water to cover them.

steps.headline: Bring 4 cups (1 L) of water to a boil.
steps.description: Cook the asparagus until barely tender, about 3 minutes. Drain in a colander and transfer to a large bowl of ice and cold water. When cool, drain and set aside. If you wish, you can cut off and discard bottom halves of asparagus spears. Rinse the asparagus with filtered water first.

steps.headline: Combine lettuce leaves and sunflower sprouts in a large bowl.
steps.description: Add half of the reserved vinaigrette and toss carefully just until coated.

steps.headline: Divide lettuce and sprouts among 4 plates, starting with the largest leaves for the bottom layer.
steps.description: Sprinkle each pile of greens with asparagus, cucumber, bell pepper, and radishes. Drizzle the vegetables with a little more vinaigrette. Cut off and discard bottom halves of asparagus spears.

steps.headline: Place 1 tablespoon of cheese on the salad and serve with remaining vinaigrette and sea salt for seasoning if you like.
steps.description: You can use other seasoning if you like but it may not taste the same.

steps.headline: Heat 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of vegetable oil in a skillet.
steps.description: Tilt the skillet around so that the oil coats it evenly first, then set the skillet down on the burner. Turn the heat up to high, and let the oil heat up; it's ready when it starts to bubble. You can use another type of oil if you want something more flavorful, such as peanut oil. Vegetable oil is recommended because it won’t impart a strong flavor to the sunflower sprouts.

steps.headline: Add 1 small chopped onion and fry it for 2 minutes.
steps.description: If you have not already, prepare 1 small onion by peeling the papery outer layer first, then cutting off both ends. Chop the onion into small pieces, then toss them into the skillet. Fry it for 2 minutes, stirring it often with a wooden spatula. You can omit this step if you don’t like onion, or replace it with 1 clove of garlic instead.

steps.headline: Add 2 cups (200 g) of sunflower sprouts and season with salt.
steps.description: Rinse the sunflower sprouts with filtered water first, then add them to the skillet. Season them with a 1/2 teaspoon of salt, then give them a stir. If you want to, you can remove the brownish threads at the ends of the white roots first.

steps.headline: Sauté the sunflower sprouts over medium heat for 3 to 5 minutes.
steps.description: Stir them often with a wooden spatula as they fry, otherwise they won’t cook often. They are ready when they start to turn translucent and golden. This will take about 2 to 5 minutes. Be careful not to overcook them, however, or they will start to turn mushy.

steps.headline: Serve the sunflower sprouts immediately.
steps.description: Like most fried foods, sautéed sunflower sprouts should not sit too long. Once they are ready, slide them off of the skillet and onto a serving dish. Sautéed sunflower sprouts make a great side dish.

steps.headline: Combine the peanut oil, scallions, ginger, and garlic in a wok.
steps.description: Pour enough peanut oil into a wok to lightly coat the surface--about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) should be enough. Add 1/2 cup (50 g) of thinly-sliced scallions, 1 tablespoon minced ginger, and 1 tablespoon sliced garlic. Give everything a brief stir with a wooden spatula. If you don’t like peanut oil, you can use another stir frying oil instead, such as canola or vegetable.

steps.headline: Fry the ingredients over high heat until they become fragrant.
steps.description: This will take about 1 to 2 minutes. Stir them often with a wooden spatula so that they cook evenly and don't burn. You’re not quite done cooking yet - don’t worry if the ingredients don’t look cooked.

steps.headline: Season the ingredients with salt and pepper.
steps.description: Start with a pinch of salt and a few shakes of pepper, then stir the ingredients again. Don’t worry if this doesn’t seem like a lot for now; you can always season the sunflower sprouts further later.

steps.headline: Add 1 pound (450 g) of sunflower sprouts and cook for 2 to 3 minutes.
steps.description: Rinse the sunflower sprouts first, then add them into the wok. Stir them to distribute the other ingredients evenly, then fry them for 2 to 3 minutes, stirring often. Remove the little brown hairs at the ends of the white roots first. Do not overcook the sunflower sprouts, or they will turn mushy.

steps.headline: Serve the stir fry immediately.
steps.description: Once the bean sprouts are done, slide them off the wok and into a bowl. Serve them immediately, or they will lose their texture. For a more filling meal, serve over steamed rice.

Bring 4 cups (1 L) of water to a boil. Cook over medium to high heat. This will be enough for 9 ounces (255 g) of sunflower sprouts. You can prepare more sunflower sprouts if you want to, but you'll need to add more water. If you are cooking more bean sprouts, use enough water to cover them. Bring 4 cups (1 L) of water to a boil. Cook the asparagus until barely tender, about 3 minutes. Drain in a colander and transfer to a large bowl of ice and cold water. When cool, drain and set aside. If you wish, you can cut off and discard bottom halves of asparagus spears. Rinse the asparagus with filtered water first. Combine lettuce leaves and sunflower sprouts in a large bowl. Add half of the reserved vinaigrette and toss carefully just until coated. Divide lettuce and sprouts among 4 plates, starting with the largest leaves for the bottom layer. Sprinkle each pile of greens with asparagus, cucumber, bell pepper, and radishes. Drizzle the vegetables with a little more vinaigrette. Cut off and discard bottom halves of asparagus spears. Place 1 tablespoon of cheese on the salad and serve with remaining vinaigrette and sea salt for seasoning if you like. You can use other seasoning if you like but it may not taste the same. Sautéed Sunflower Sprouts Heat 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of vegetable oil in a skillet. Tilt the skillet around so that the oil coats it evenly first, then set the skillet down on the burner. Turn the heat up to high, and let the oil heat up; it's ready when it starts to bubble. You can use another type of oil if you want something more flavorful, such as peanut oil. Vegetable oil is recommended because it won’t impart a strong flavor to the sunflower sprouts. Add 1 small chopped onion and fry it for 2 minutes. If you have not already, prepare 1 small onion by peeling the papery outer layer first, then cutting off both ends. Chop the onion into small pieces, then toss them into the skillet. Fry it for 2 minutes, stirring it often with a wooden spatula. You can omit this step if you don’t like onion, or replace it with 1 clove of garlic instead. Add 2 cups (200 g) of sunflower sprouts and season with salt. Rinse the sunflower sprouts with filtered water first, then add them to the skillet. Season them with a 1/2 teaspoon of salt, then give them a stir. If you want to, you can remove the brownish threads at the ends of the white roots first. Sauté the sunflower sprouts over medium heat for 3 to 5 minutes. Stir them often with a wooden spatula as they fry, otherwise they won’t cook often. They are ready when they start to turn translucent and golden. This will take about 2 to 5 minutes. Be careful not to overcook them, however, or they will start to turn mushy. Serve the sunflower sprouts immediately. Like most fried foods, sautéed sunflower sprouts should not sit too long. Once they are ready, slide them off of the skillet and onto a serving dish. Sautéed sunflower sprouts make a great side dish. Making Stir-Fried Sunflower Sprouts Combine the peanut oil, scallions, ginger, and garlic in a wok. Pour enough peanut oil into a wok to lightly coat the surface--about 1 tablespoon (15 mL) should be enough. Add 1/2 cup (50 g) of thinly-sliced scallions, 1 tablespoon minced ginger, and 1 tablespoon sliced garlic. Give everything a brief stir with a wooden spatula. If you don’t like peanut oil, you can use another stir frying oil instead, such as canola or vegetable. Fry the ingredients over high heat until they become fragrant. This will take about 1 to 2 minutes. Stir them often with a wooden spatula so that they cook evenly and don't burn. You’re not quite done cooking yet - don’t worry if the ingredients don’t look cooked. Season the ingredients with salt and pepper. Start with a pinch of salt and a few shakes of pepper, then stir the ingredients again. Don’t worry if this doesn’t seem like a lot for now; you can always season the sunflower sprouts further later. Add 1 pound (450 g) of sunflower sprouts and cook for 2 to 3 minutes. Rinse the sunflower sprouts first, then add them into the wok. Stir them to distribute the other ingredients evenly, then fry them for 2 to 3 minutes, stirring often. Remove the little brown hairs at the ends of the white roots first. Do not overcook the sunflower sprouts, or they will turn mushy. Serve the stir fry immediately. Once the bean sprouts are done, slide them off the wok and into a bowl. Serve them immediately, or they will lose their texture. For a more filling meal, serve over steamed rice.
